description.narrative: Stödet till UNFPA, som är ett komplement till UNFPAs kärnstöd, syftar till att förbättra indikatorerna inom hälsosektorn gällande mödra-och barnhälsovård, förebyggande av HIV och allmänna insatser för att minska fattigdomen som ett resultat av ohälsa. Stödet är i linje med målen för hälsosektorn: förbättrad tillgång till hälso- och sjukvård för fattiga människor och minskad spridning av HIV/AIDS.

The support to UNFPA, which is complimentary to UNFPA core support, aims to contribute to improving the health sector indicators under maternal and child health, HIV prevention as well general interventions to alleviate poverty as a results of ill health. Sweden has supported UNFPA core and project support since 2011. The support in line with the health sector objective.

Update as of 24 April 2015:The overall goal of the project is to improve the status of sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) of the people of UgandaObjectives: within 24 months time from project start:1) To increase coverage for selected sexual and reproductive health services in the 8 UNFPA/GOU country program focus districts and 5 HIV thematic districts2) To strengthen capacity of leadership of 9 cultural and 3 religious institutions for their (re)engagement in HIV prevention and promotion of FP/MH and GBV services

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: This was a continuation (phase II) of the project support to UNFPA in 2011-2012. This contribution ended as agreed, after no-cost extensions, on the 31st December 2015. A Final statement on Narrative report and Financial statement was then done by responsible PO on the 29th July 2016. The Embassy received the final Financial statement in June 2017, but the completion memo remained. This completion memo is therefore a summary of what was stated in the final statement on reports and COP. Overall the support to “Strengthening Capacity for Maternal Health and Youth Friendly Services Provision and HIV Prevention Leadership in Uganda” has achieved the intended outcomes. The seven outputs within the programme cut across the two main objectives: 1. To increase coverage for selected sexual and reproductive health services in the eight UNFPA/GoU country program focus districts and five HIV thematic districts 2. To strengthen capacity of leaderships of 9 cultural and 3 religious institutions for their (re)engagements in HIV prevention and promotion of FP/MH and GBV services In relation to the first objective, the programme had; a 91% increase of Family Planning users in the eight UNFPA/GoU districts (From baseline 125 877 (2012) to 241 145 (2015)), a 40-64% increase in health facility delivery in each of the 8 districts, 310 112 young people reached in youth friendly corners (compared to 70 000 in 2012) and 72% mothers enrolled on ARVs for eMTCT. Some of the activities carried out to achieve these results have been: Establishing 10 new youth corners in the five HIV theme districts and supporting an additional 24 youth corners to provide routine youth friendly services, through technical advice from WHO 34 youth friendly corners have been supported in Central Uganda, 264 midwives have been trained and also signed bonding agreements with the target districts, family planning commodities have been procured and delivered to contribute to the implementation of the national contraceptive procurement plan and avoid stock outs at national level. Regarding the second objective the programme have led to that 12 (out of the planned 9) cultural institutions have made pronouncements to denounce harmful practices and promote use of SRH, GBV and HIV prevention services and 3 religious institutions have produced and printed religious handbooks to guide advocacy for increased access to HIV prevention, FP/ MH and GBV prevention. Some of the activities carried out to reach the results were to train and equip 1257 leaders including clergy, lay leaders, catechists, and youth on how to use the handbooks and utilize these in educating their congregants on SRH, HIV and GBV Prevention, produce study reports and policy briefs for each of the 12 cultural institutions. It is estimated that cultural and religious leaders reached over 3 million people with HIV/SRH/MNH/GBV information in the target districts. The program also supported a multimedia behavior change communication program in 11 target districts. The programme reached about 2 590 000 listeners. Altogether the program supported the production of 360 radio programmes and airing of 456 radio programmes. Through feedback from callers during the radio programme, feedback from VHTs and through FGDs during monitoring visits the following was reported: increased knowledge on RH and GBV, utilization of skilled delivery services at health facilities, increased male involvement during Antenatal care as seen through more men going with their partners to seek services, seeking HIV testing services, accepting family planning methods, parents talking to their children about teenage pregnancy prevention and mothers appreciating the importance of reporting back to health centres for post-natal care.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
